prompt:
You are a security expert.
        Categorize the following incident description into a Category and an Explanation.

        Description:
            ``` [target]: [[DATE_TIME_f2dd869363] 08:14 CERT.br: 
Data de envio: Feb 7, 2023 8:12 AM
Para: "NFOservers.com DDoS notifier" <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_92a6206f7f]>, [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Re: Compromised host used for an attack: [IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f] [~164 Mbps]

Hello,

CERT.br works as a coordinating team for incidents and abuses related
to Brazilian networks. We are listed in the "remarks" notes of the
Brazilian Whois Server output to receive copies of complaints, but we
are not the technical or abuse contact of any network.

We are forwarding your email to the proper contacts for this network
so they can handle this incident.

Original message was attached to this email.

Thank you for reporting this incident,
--
CERT.br/NIC.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

=======================================================================
----- Original message as text -----
From: [ORGANIZATION_1df86da352] DDoS notifier <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_92a6206f7f]>
To: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Subject: Compromised host used for an attack: [IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f] [~164 Mbps]
Date: Mon, 6 Feb 2023 23:54:03 -0800
Message-ID: <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_bfe4da8091]>

An IP address ([IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f]) under your control appears to have attacked one of our customers as part of a coordinated DDoS botnet. We manually reviewed the captures from this attack and do not believe that your IP address was spoofed, based on the limited number of distinct hosts attacking us, the identicality of many attacking IP addresses to ones we've seen in the past, and the non-random distribution of IP addresses.

It is possible that this host is one of the following, from the responses that others have sent us:

- A compromised router, such as a [ORGANIZATION_4fa360a1dd] that is running with WAN access enabled; a [ORGANIZATION_9954db40ae] which still allows a default admin username and password; a Netis, with a built-in internet-accessible backdoor ([URL_2764a7b048]); or one running an old AirOS version with a vulnerable and exposed administrative interface
- An [ORGANIZATION_8df3b93efb] device that is vulnerable to compromise (such as HTV), either directly through the default firmware or through a trojan downloaded app
- A compromised webhost, such as one running a vulnerable version of Drupal (for instance, using the vulnerability discussed at [URL_9346d9f602]), WordPress, phpMyAdmin, or zPanel
- A compromised DVR, such as a "Hikvision" brand device (ref: [URL_2002177763])
- A compromised IPMI device, such as one made by [ORGANIZATION_e8804ebb01] (possibly because it uses the default U/P of ADMIN/ADMIN or because its password was found through an exploit described at [URL_643058c363])
- A compromised Xerox-branded device
- Some other compromised standalone device
- A server with an insecure password that was brute-forced, such as through SSH or RDP
- A server running an improperly secured Hadoop installation
- A server running a pre-13.10.3 GitLab instance that is vulnerable to CVE-2021-22205
- A compromised [ORGANIZATION_c7bac46904] DNS server (through the July 2020 critical vulnerability)

The overall botnet attack was Nx10Gbps in size (with traffic from your host as well as some others) and caused significant packet loss for our clients due to external link saturation. It required an emergency null-route operation on our side to mitigate.

Attacks like this are usually made very short, intentionally, so that they are not as noticeable and slip past certain automatic mitigation systems. From your side, you would be able to observe the attack as a burst of traffic that likely saturated the network adapter of the source device for perhaps 30 seconds. Since the source de]
            ```
        
        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.
            Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack.
        - CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks.
            Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits.

        Your task:
        - Classify the incident below using the most appropriate category code (CAT1 to CAT12).
        - Justify based on the explanation of the selected category.
         
        If classification is not possible, return:
        Category: Unknown
        Explanation: Unknown
        
        OUTPUT:
        Category: [NIST code]
        Explanation: [Justification for the chosen category]

The key here is that the incident is a DDoS attack.

- CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts. (Not applicable: the incident is about DDoS, not account compromise)
- CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code. (The incident doesn't specify malware, but note that the attacker might have compromised a device with malware. However, the primary issue here is the DDoS attack, which is a consequence of the compromise. But the category we are classifying is the incident as described: the DDoS attack itself. The report says the host is compromised and then used for the attack. So the incident is the attack, not the malware itself.)
- CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable. (This category explicitly includes "volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server". This matches perfectly: the incident is a DDoS botnet attack that caused denial of service for CERT.br's customers.)
- CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data. (No data leak mentioned)
- CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks. (The incident does mention that the compromised device might have been due to vulnerabilities, but the incident itself is the DDoS attack. The report is about the attack, not the exploitation of a vulnerability per se. However, note the email says: "It is possible that this host is one of the following..." which lists vulnerabilities. But the primary classification for the incident is the DDoS attack.)
- CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users. (Not applicable)
- CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data. (Not applicable)
- CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access. (Not applicable)
- CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data. (Not applicable)

- CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers. (Not applicable)
- CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks. (The attack has been confirmed: CERT.br received evidence of the attack. So it's not an unconfirmed attempt.)

Given that the incident is a DDoS attack (which is a type of Denial of Service Attack), the most appropriate category is CAT3.

The NIST CAT3 definition: "Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable." and examples include "volumetric DoS or DDoS".

Therefore, the category should be CAT3.

Explanation: The incident involves a coordinated DDoS botnet attack that caused significant packet loss and required an emergency null-route operation to mitigate, which directly falls under the Denial of Service Attack category.

So:

Category: CAT3

The attack is the result of the compromise, but the incident as described by CERT.br is the attack event. Therefore, the incident is the DDoS attack, which is a denial of service.

CERT.br works as a coordinating team for incidents and abuses related
to Brazilian networks. We are listed in the "remarks" notes of the
Brazilian Whois Server output to receive copies of complaints, but we
are not the technical or abuse contact of any network.

CERT.br/NIC.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>

----- Original message as text -----
From: [ORGANIZATION_1df86da352] DDoS notifier <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_92a6206f7f]>
To: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Subject: Compromised host used for an attack: [IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f] [~164 Mbps]
Date: Mon, 6 Feb 2023 23:54:03 -0800
Message-ID: <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_bfe4da8091]>

An IP address ([IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f]) under your control appears to have attacked one of our customers as part of a coordinated DDoS botnet. We manually reviewed the captures from this attack and do not believe that your IP address was spoofed, based on the limited number of distinct hosts attacking us, the identicality of many attacking IP addresses to ones we've seen in the past, and the non-random distribution of IP addresses.

It is possible that this host is one of the following, from the responses that others have sent us:

- A compromised router, such as a [ORGANIZATION_4fa360a1dd] that is running with WAN access enabled; a [ORGANIZATION_9954db40ae] which still allows a default admin username and password; a Netis, with a built-in internet-accessible backdoor ([URL_2764a7b048]); or one running an old AirOS version with a vulnerable and exposed administrative interface
- An [ORGANIZATION_8df3b93efb] device that is vulnerable to compromise (such as HTV), either directly through the default firmware or through a trojan downloaded app
- A compromised webhost, such as one running a vulnerable version of Drupal (for instance, using the vulnerability discussed at [URL_9346d9f602]), WordPress, phpMyAdmin, or zPanel
- A compromised DVR, such as a "Hikvision" brand device (ref: [URL_2002177763])
- A compromised IPMI device, such as one made by [ORGANIZATION_e8804ebb01] (possibly because it uses the default U/P of ADMIN/ADMIN or because its password was found through an exploit described at [URL_643058c363])
- A compromised Xerox-branded device
- Some other compromised standalone device
- A server with an insecure password that was brute-forced, such as through SSH or RDP
- A server running an improperly secured Hadoop installation
- A server running a pre-13.10.3 GitLab instance that is vulnerable to CVE-2021-22205
- A compromised [ORGANIZATION_c7bac46904] DNS server (through the July 2020 critical vulnerability)

The overall botnet attack was Nx10Gbps in size (with traffic from your host as well as some others) and caused significant packet loss for our clients due to external link saturation. It required an emergency null-route operation on our side to mitigate.

Attacks like this are usually made very short, intentionally, so that they are not as noticeable and slip past certain automatic mitigation systems. From your side, you would be able to observe the attack as a burst of traffic that likely saturated the network adapter of the source device for perhaps 30 seconds. Since the source de]

            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.

        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.

        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.

prompt:
You are a security expert.
        Categorize the following incident description into a Category and an Explanation.

        Description:
            ``` [target]: [[DATE_TIME_232aece9f1] 15:55 CERT.br: 
Data de envio: Jun 1, 2023 3:49 PM
Para: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servidor NTP mal configurado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são servidores NTP mal configurados sob
sua responsabilidade (123/udp). Estes servidores podem ser abusados
para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação de serviço,
consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados também podem ser dispositivos
de rede com funcionalidade NTP, como roteadores e CPEs (modem ou
roteador de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes).

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* Os servidores NTP listados sejam configurados de modo a corrigir
 este problema.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
servidores NTP mal configurados, por favor repasse essa mensagem para
alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

Os indicadores no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indicam os tipos de
problemas testados e significam:

* monlist: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes são o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

* readvar: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status pode ser "timeout",
   "open" ou "closed", e pacotes/bytes sao o tamanho da resposta
   recebida, em pacotes/bytes;

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_f36fd7c474]    | 2716   | OPEN   | 2023-06-01T18:04:02Z | monlist: timeout/0/0, readvar: open/1/400
====================================================================================

Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é um servidor NTP mal configurado e passível de amplificação?

Um servidor NTP é considerado mal configurado e passível de
  amplificação quando aceita determinados comandos, como monlist ou
  readvar, que permitem gerar respostas muito maiores que a pergunta,
  para origens forjadas.

### Category: CAT12  
**Explanation:** The incident describes a misconfigured NTP server vulnerability that *could* be exploited for amplification attacks (a type of DDoS attack). This is a **potential unconfirmed attack attempt** (as per NIST CAT12), not an active attack or confirmed exploitation. CERT.br is proactively notifying the recipient about vulnerable systems that are *at risk* of being targeted (e.g., via network scans for the `monlist`/`readvar` commands), but no actual attack has been confirmed to have succeeded. The examples for CAT12 explicitly include "network scans" and "blocked exploits" — here, the misconfiguration represents a target for such scans, where attackers might attempt to abuse the server without the vulnerability being actively exploited yet. This fits CAT12 better than CAT3 (which requires an active DDoS attack) or CAT5 (which requires confirmed exploitation). 

**Why not other categories?**  
- **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)**: Incorrect, as the incident describes a *vulnerability risk* (potential for DDoS), not an active attack.

- **CAT10 (Misuse of Resources)**: Incorrect, as this refers to *active unauthorized usage* (e.g., current misuse), but here the issue is a *vulnerability detection* that could lead to misuse.  
- Other categories (CAT1–CAT9, CAT11) are irrelevant to the described scenario.  

**Key distinction**: CAT12 covers *unconfirmed* attack attempts (e.g., scans, probes) that are detected but not yet confirmed to have succeeded — which aligns with CERT.br's notification about vulnerable systems *awaiting mitigation*. This is a classic example of proactive vulnerability scanning leading to an unconfirmed intrusion attempt.

* O que é um servidor NTP mal configurado e passível de amplificação?

Um servidor NTP é considerado mal configurado e passível de
  amplificação quando aceita determinados comandos, como monlist ou
  readvar, que permitem gerar respostas muito maiores que a pergunta,
  para origens forjadas.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

Um servidor NTP mal configurado pode ser abusado para causar danos a
  terceiros, envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações,
  além de implicar em um maior consumo de banda.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtrados aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema em sistemas Unix?

1. Desabilite o comando "monlist".  Isso pode ser feito de duas
      maneiras:

- Inclua no ntpd.conf a seguinte linha:

disable monitor

- Instale a versao 4.2.7p26 ou mais atual, que não possui o
       comando monlist.

2. Desabilite o comando "readvar"

- Inclua no ntpd.conf as seguintes linhas:

restrict default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery
       restrict -6 default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery

response:
Okay, the user wants me to classify a specific incident description from CERT.br about misconfigured NTP servers that are vulnerable to DDoS amplification attacks. They've provided detailed background and need me to pick the most appropriate NIST category (CAT1 to CAT12) with an explanation.

First, I need to carefully analyze what happened here. The incident involves NTP servers that allow `monlist` and `readvar` commands - these are misconfigurations that attackers can exploit to launch amplification attacks. The key point is that these servers could be used in DDoS attacks where small requests generate large responses, consuming network resources.

The user has already done some good work by eliminating other categories:
- CAT1 (Account Compromise): Not relevant here
- CAT2 (Malware): This is a misconfiguration issue, not malware
- CAT4 (Data Leak): No data leakage mentioned
- CAT6-9: All seem unrelated to this specific vulnerability
- CAT10 (Misuse of Resources): While DDoS does misuse resources, the category description focuses on crypto mining/malware distribution which doesn't fit
- CAT11 (Third-Party Issues): This is an internal misconfiguration, not a third-party supplier problem
- CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt): The description says CERT.br found vulnerable servers (a vulnerability scan), not an active intrusion attempt

Now focusing on CAT3 and CAT5:
- CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack) describes active DoS/DDoS attacks that make systems unavailable. But in this case, the incident is a *vulnerability notification* - not an active attack that's already happened. CERT.br is informing about potential risks, not reporting that an attack has occurred.
- CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation) covers "using technical flaws for attacks". This fits perfectly because the misconfiguration is a technical flaw that could be exploited to conduct amplification attacks (which are a form of volumetric DoS). The incident description is about the vulnerability being found and could be exploited.

I recall that in NIST frameworks, vulnerability disclosures like this are typically classified under vulnerability exploitation categories because they represent conditions that could lead to attacks. The category definition explicitly mentions "exploitation of critical CVE" and similar scenarios - this misconfiguration is essentially a critical vulnerability that could be exploited for amplification attacks.

The user's hypothesis points to CAT5 as the answer. They're very thorough in their analysis - they even considered whether it's an active attack (which it isn't) versus a potential attack vector. 

Important nuance: The incident is the *notification* about vulnerability, not the actual attack. But in security incident classification, such notifications are considered incidents because they represent a security risk that needs addressing. NIST CAT5 covers exactly this - vulnerabilities that can be exploited.

So I'll go with CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation. The explanation should emphasize that this is a technical flaw (misconfiguration) that can be actively exploited for DDoS amplification attacks, which aligns with CAT5's examples of technical flaws being used for attacks.
</think>

### Category: CAT5  
**Explanation:**  
This incident falls under **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation** because it describes a *technical flaw* (misconfigured NTP servers allowing `monlist` and `readvar` commands) that **can be actively exploited** to conduct DDoS amplification attacks. The NIST definition for CAT5 explicitly covers "using technical flaws for attacks," with examples including "exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection." Here:  
- The misconfiguration is a **critical technical vulnerability** (an NTP server flaw that enables amplification attacks).  
- CERT.br's notification identifies that this vulnerability *could be exploited* by attackers to launch volumetric DDoS attacks (where small requests generate large responses), directly matching CAT5's focus on **exploitable technical flaws**.  
- Unlike CAT3 (which requires an *active* DoS/DDoS attack that has already made systems unavailable), this incident describes a *potential vulnerability* that, if exploited, would cause such an attack. Since the incident notification itself is about the *existence* of a flaw that enables exploitation (not an executed attack), CAT5 is the most precise fit.  

**Why not other categories?**  
- **CAT3 (Denial of Service Attack)**: Incorrect because CAT3 applies *only when an active DoS/DDoS attack has already occurred* (e.g., UDP floods making systems unavailable). Here, the incident is a *vulnerability notification*—not an active attack.  
- **CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt)**: Incorrect because this describes a *proactive vulnerability scan* (CERT.br identifying misconfigurations), not an unconfirmed intrusion attempt (e.g., brute-force scans or exploits).  
- Other categories (CAT1–4, 6–11) are irrelevant, as established in the analysis.  

**Key insight**: NIST classification focuses on *actual incidents* (events with impact). Here, CERT.br's notification constitutes an **incident of vulnerability exploitation risk**—a critical precursor to a real attack. CAT5 is the only category that covers *technical flaws that can be exploited* (as described in the incident), making it the most appropriate fit.  

> ✅ **Final Answer**: Category = **CAT5**  
> *Rationale: This is a technical vulnerability (misconfiguration) that, if exploited, enables DDoS amplification attacks—directly aligning with NIST's definition of "Vulnerability Exploitation."*

        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.

        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.

        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.
        - CAT8: Physical Incident – impact due to unauthorized physical access.
            Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in.
        - CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – improper changes to systems or data.
            Examples: defacement, record manipulation.
        - CAT10: Misuse of Resources – unauthorized use for other purposes.
            Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution.
        - CAT11: Third-Party Issues – security failures by suppliers.
            Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack.
        - CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks.
            Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits.

        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.
            Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage.
        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.
            Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud.

        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.
            Examples: exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection in web applications.
        - CAT6: Insider Abuse – malicious actions by internal users.

        - CAT7: Social Engineering – deception to gain access or data.

Now, let's map this to the NIST categories:

- **CAT1: Account Compromise** – This category includes unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts. The example includes "SSH brute force".

However, note that the attack is not yet successful (the logs show failed attempts). But the NIST definition of CAT1 includes "SSH brute force" as an example.

But note: The NIST categories are designed to capture the nature of the incident. In this case, the incident is a **brute force attack** that has been detected and reported.

The logs here show the attack is happening (the failed attempts) but the attack has not been successful. Also, the category examples include "brute force".

The key point: The NIST categories are intended to be used for classifying incidents that have been detected. In this case, the incident is a reported brute force attempt (which is an active attack). 

Looking at the official NIST definitions:

- CAT1: "Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts." 
  - Examples: "credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft"

- CAT12: "Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks"
  - Examples: "network scans, brute force, blocked exploits"

The distinction is that CAT1 is for when the account compromise has actually occurred (the account was taken over), while CAT12 is for attempts that are not yet confirmed (i.e., the attack is in progress but hasn't succeeded).

In this incident:
- The logs show multiple failed attempts. There has been no successful compromise (the accounts were not taken). 
- Therefore, this is an **unconfirmed attack** (the attack is happening but hasn't succeeded).

Thus, the appropriate category is **CAT12**.

Why not CAT1?
- CAT1 is for when the account compromise has occurred (the attacker has gained access). Here, the attack has failed. So it's not a compromise.

Why not CAT12?
- CAT12 is defined as "unconfirmed attacks" (meaning the attack is happening but hasn't been confirmed to have succeeded). This fits perfectly because:
  - The attack is a brute force attempt (as per the logs).
  - The attack is unconfirmed (it has not succeeded) and has been reported (by the user) but the system hasn't taken action yet (the network owner is being notified to handle it).

Therefore, the classification is:

Category: CAT12
Explanation: The incident describes a brute force attack on SSH accounts from the same IP address (multiple failed login attempts) which has not yet resulted in account compromise. This fits under CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt) as it is an unconfirmed attack attempt (brute force) that has been detected and reported.

- CAT2: Malware – Not applicable (no malware mentioned).
- CAT3: DoS – Not applicable (the attack is targeted at SSH logins, not a DoS).

- CAT11: Third-Party Issues – Not applicable (the issue is with the network owner's system).

Conclusion: The most appropriate category is **CAT12**.

response:
We are given an incident description and a list of NIST categories (CAT1 to CAT12). We need to categorize the incident into the most appropriate category and provide an explanation.

Let's break down the incident description:

1. The email chain starts with a complaint from a user (root) about abuse from an IP address [IP_ADDRESS_b29a075d57]. The user claims that they detected abuse (specifically multiple failed SSH login attempts) on the target network.

2. The original message (from root) includes log lines from the target system (the server named "rudra") showing multiple failed SSH authentication attempts from the IP address [IP_ADDRESS_b29a075d57]. The attempts were for invalid usernames (dani, tracy, wrc, uftp, kiri, joan). The timestamps are from March 24, 2022.

3. CERT.br (a Brazilian CERT) is forwarding this to the proper contacts for the network because they are listed in the Whois server as a recipient for complaints.

Key points from the logs:
- The IP address [IP_ADDRESS_b29a075d57] is attempting to log in to SSH (port 22) using invalid usernames.
- The attempts are happening at different times on the same day (Mar 24, 2022) and are being blocked by the SSH server (as seen by the "authentication failure" messages).
- The email mentions that the message was generated by Fail2Ban (a tool that blocks repeated failed login attempts). The note says: "This mail was generated by Fail2Ban."

What is happening?
- The IP address is performing a brute-force attack on SSH. It is trying multiple usernames (with invalid usernames) and failing each time. This is a classic SSH brute-force attack.

Now, let's map to the NIST categories:

- CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts. 
   - This incident involves failed attempts (so no actual account compromise has occurred yet) but the attack is intended to compromise accounts. However, the description says "unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts" (which implies they have gotten in). Here, the attacks are blocked and the accounts are not compromised (so not CAT1).

- CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code. 
   - There's no mention of malware. The attack is a brute force, so not malware.

- CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable. 
   - The attack is not a DoS. It's a brute force on SSH, which is a different type of attack.

- CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data. 
   - Not applicable.

- CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.

The original message from the user (root) reports multiple failed SSH login attempts from the IP address [IP_ADDRESS_b29a075d57]. The CERT.br is forwarding the email to the proper network contacts for investigation.

Key points from the description:
- The incident involves repeated failed SSH login attempts (invalid user attempts) from the same IP address (b29a075d57) over a short period (Mar 24, 2022).
- The email was generated by Fail2Ban, which is a tool that monitors and blocks brute force attacks on SSH servers.
- The report states: "We have detected abuse from the IP address ... which according to a whois lookup is on your network."

The NIST categories:

We need to map the incident to one of the 12 categories.

Let's break down:

1. **CAT1: Account Compromise** - unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts. 
   - The incident shows failed attempts, not successful compromise. So not CAT1.

2. **CAT2: Malware** - infection by malicious code. 
   - There's no indication of malware being present. The report is about brute force attempts, not malware.

3. **CAT3: Denial of Service Attack** - making systems unavailable. 
   - The incident is not a DoS attack but rather a brute force attempt on SSH (which is an authentication attack). DoS typically aims to make the system unavailable, but here the system is functioning and the attacker is trying to log in multiple times. This is not a DoS.

4. **CAT4: Data Leak** - unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data. 
   - Not applicable; there's no data leak reported.

5. **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation** - using technical flaws for attacks.
   - The attack here is brute force on SSH (which is a vulnerability in the sense that the SSH server is exposed and not protected against brute force). However, note that the attack is a brute force attempt, which is a common attack pattern that exploits the lack of rate limiting or other security measures. But the category says "using technical flaws for attacks". The technical flaw here is the absence of rate limiting on SSH, but the incident is an attempt, not necessarily an exploitation of a specific vulnerability. However, note that the incident is an intrusion attempt (brute force) that could be considered as exploiting a vulnerability (the SSH service being vulnerable to brute force).

6. **CAT6: Insider Abuse** - malicious actions by internal users. 
   - Not applicable; the attacker is external.

7. **CAT7: Social Engineering** - deception to gain access or data. 
   - The report was generated by Fail2Ban (an automated tool) and the email was sent by a user (root) who detected the abuse. There's no social engineering in the incident itself.

8. **CAT8: Physical Incident** - impact due to unauthorized physical access. 
   - Not applicable.

9. **CAT9: Unauthorized Modification** - improper changes to systems or data. 
   - Not applicable.

10. **CAT10: Misuse of Resources** - unauthorized use for other purposes. 
    - Not applicable.

11. **CAT11: Third-Party Issues** - security failures by suppliers. 
    - Not applicable.

12. **CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – unconfirmed attacks** - Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits.
    - This category explicitly mentions "brute force" as an example. The incident is a brute force attack on SSH (multiple failed login attempts from the same IP). The report says: "We have detected abuse from the IP address ... which according to a whois lookup is on your network". The attacker is trying to brute force the SSH server.

    Note: The incident is an unconfirmed attack (the attack has been detected but not yet confirmed as successful). The CERT.br is forwarding to the network contacts to take action. So it's an intrusion attempt that has been detected but not yet completed (the attacker hasn't succeeded in gaining access).

    Therefore, the most appropriate category is CAT12.

Let's check the examples for CAT12: "Examples: network scans, brute force, blocked exploits." 
- This incident is a brute force attack (multiple failed SSH logins). The attacker is trying to break in by guessing passwords (brute force). The attack is unconfirmed because the attacker hasn't succeeded (as per the log lines, all attempts failed).

Also note: The incident is described as an "abuse" from the IP address, which is a common scenario for brute force attacks.

Conclusion: 
- Category: CAT12
- Explanation: The incident describes multiple failed SSH login attempts from the same IP address (brute force attack) detected by Fail2Ban. This is an unconfirmed intrusion attempt (brute force) that matches the description of CAT12.

Let's rule out others:
- CAT5: While the attack exploits a vulnerability (lack of rate limiting on SSH), the incident is specifically an intrusion attempt that is being reported and is blocked (as the attacks are failing). The NIST category CAT12 is designed for such unconfirmed attacks. Also, note that the example for CAT5 is "exploitation of critical CVE, remote code execution (RCE), SQL injection". This is not an exploitation of a specific critical vulnerability but rather a brute force attack that might be mitigated by the SSH server configuration.

Therefore, the answer is CAT12.

Output:
Category: CAT12
Explanation: The incident involves multiple failed SSH login attempts (brute force) from the same IP address, which is an unconfirmed intrusion attempt. This matches CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt) as it describes network scans, brute force, and blocked exploits.
</think>

Category: CAT12  
Explanation: The incident describes repeated failed SSH login attempts (invalid user logins) from a single IP address (`[IP_ADDRESS_b29a075d57]`) over a short timeframe (March 24, 2022). This pattern is characteristic of a brute-force attack, where the attacker is attempting to compromise credentials through automated trial-and-error. The email was generated by Fail2Ban (an intrusion detection/prevention tool) and explicitly states the abuse is "detected" but not yet successful (all attempts failed). This aligns with CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt) as it represents an unconfirmed, ongoing attack attempt that has been detected but not yet completed (e.g., blocked exploits or brute force). The other categories are not applicable:  
- CAT1 (Account Compromise): No successful account compromise occurred (all attempts failed).  
- CAT5 (Vulnerability Exploitation): This refers to exploiting specific technical flaws (e.g., CVEs), but the incident is a generic brute-force attack, not a targeted exploit of a specific vulnerability.  
- CAT12 is the most precise match per NIST's examples (brute force is explicitly listed as an "intrusion attempt").

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]
            ```

We are given an incident description from CERT.br about SNMP service being enabled on devices that are potentially being abused for DDoS attacks.

Key points:
- The issue: SNMP service (161/udp) is open and accessible to the internet, which can be exploited for DDoS amplification attacks.
- The notification is that the organization (ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4) has devices that are vulnerable and might be being used in such attacks.
- The incident is a notification of a vulnerability (exposed SNMP) that could be exploited, not an active attack.

We need to choose from NIST categories CAT1 to CAT12.

Let's review the NIST categories and the incident:

- CAT1: Account Compromise - Not applicable (no account compromise mentioned).
- CAT2: Malware - The incident doesn't involve malware infection.
- CAT3: Denial of Service Attack - This is for when a DDoS attack has already occurred (the service is down). Here, the attack hasn't happened; it's a potential risk.
- CAT4: Data Leak - Not applicable (no data leak mentioned).
- CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation - This category is for when a vulnerability is actively being exploited (i.e., the attack has occurred). In this case, the vulnerability exists but hasn't been exploited (the service is exposed but no attack has been launched yet). The incident is a notification of the vulnerability, not the exploitation.
- CAT6: Insider Abuse - Not applicable.
- CAT7: Social Engineering - Not applicable.
- CAT8: Physical Incident - Not applicable.
- CAT9: Unauthorized Modification - Not applicable.
- CAT10: Misuse of Resources - This category includes things like cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution. The incident describes that the SNMP service could be abused for DDoS (which is a form of resource misuse in the sense of bandwidth consumption). However, the primary issue here is the vulnerability that could lead to DDoS, not an ongoing misuse. Also, the incident is about the vulnerability being exposed, not that it's currently being misused.
- CAT11: Third-Party Issues - Not applicable (the issue is with the organization's own devices).
- CAT12: Intrusion Attempt - This category covers "unconfirmed attacks", such as network scans, brute force attempts, blocked exploits. 

Why CAT12?
The incident description states that CERT.br is notifying the organization about devices that "possivelmente estão sendo abusados" (possibly being abused) and used in DDoS attacks. This implies that the devices have been identified as targets (e.g., through a scan for SNMP services) and are at risk. In the context of cybersecurity, having an exposed SNMP service (especially on a port that is vulnerable to amplification attacks) is often a result of a network scan (an intrusion attempt). Therefore, this notification can be seen as an indicator of an unconfirmed intrusion attempt (the scan for SNMP services).

The NIST definition for CAT12: "unconfirmed attacks" (e.g., network scans, brute force, blocked exploits). In this case, the organization's device has been scanned for the SNMP service (which is a common vulnerability scan target) and the device is listed as potentially being abused. This fits the "unconfirmed attack" category because the scan has been done (so there's an attempt) but it hasn't been confirmed as a successful exploitation (the attack hasn't been launched yet).

Therefore, the most appropriate category is **CAT12: Intrusion Attempt**.

Explanation: The incident involves a notification that the organization's devices have an exposed SNMP service (port 161/udp) which is a common target for network scans (an unconfirmed intrusion attempt) that could lead to DDoS amplification attacks. The CERT.br notification indicates that the devices are in a list of devices that are being scanned and might be abused, which aligns with the definition of unconfirmed attacks (such as scans) under NIST CAT12.

Let me double-check with the NIST definitions:

From NIST SP 800-61 (Computer Security Incident Handling Guide), the categories are defined as:

- CAT1: Account Compromise

Category: CAT12  
Explanation: The incident involves a notification from CERT.br identifying devices with exposed SNMP service (port 161/udp) that are **potentially being scanned and abused for DDoS amplification attacks**. This aligns with NIST CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt), which covers **unconfirmed attacks** such as network scans, brute force attempts, or blocked exploits. Here, the exposed SNMP service is a clear target for automated scans (common in vulnerability assessments), indicating an active but unconfirmed intrusion attempt (e.g., attackers probing for amplification opportunities). The incident does not represent an active DDoS attack (CAT3) or exploitation (CAT5) because the vulnerability (exposed SNMP) has not yet been successfully weaponized—only the risk of scanning and potential abuse is present. Thus, CAT12 best describes the unconfirmed scanning activity that CERT.br is highlighting as a precursor to exploitation.

Incident: 
        You are a security expert.
        Categorize the following incident description into a Category and an Explanation.

        Description:
            ``` [target]: [[DATE_TIME_c2c0b98951] 15:59 CERT.br: 
Data de envio: May 4, 2023 3:57 PM
Para: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servico SNMP habilitado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua
responsabilidade com o servico SNMP (161/udp) habilitado. Este serviço
pode ser abusado para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação
de serviço, consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados, além de servidores e
computadores, também podem ser de dispositivos de rede com o serviço
SNMP habilitado, como roteadores, impressoras, CPEs (modem ou roteador
de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes), entre outros.

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o servico SNMP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no
   equipamento, caso não esteja em uso.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SNMP habilitado, por favor repasse essa
mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* snmp: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e pacotes/bytes
   indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em pacotes/bytes.

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_2b88d034ae]     | 2716   | OPEN   | 2023-05-04T18:05:47Z | snmp: open/1/106
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]
            ```
        
        NIST Categories Available for Classification:
        - CAT1: Account Compromise – unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts.
            Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft.
        - CAT2: Malware – infection by malicious code.
            Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus.
        - CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – making systems unavailable.
            Examples: volumetric DoS or DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood, HTTP, HTTPS), attack on publicly available APIs or websites, botnet Mirai attacking an institution's server.
        - CAT4: Data Leak – unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data.
            Examples: database theft, leaked credentials.
        - CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – using technical flaws for attacks.

prompt:
You are a security expert.
        Categorize the following incident description into a Category and an Explanation.

        Description:
            ``` [target]: [[DATE_TIME_c2c0b98951] 15:59 CERT.br: 
Data de envio: May 4, 2023 3:57 PM
Para: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servico SNMP habilitado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua
responsabilidade com o servico SNMP (161/udp) habilitado. Este serviço
pode ser abusado para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação
de serviço, consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados, além de servidores e
computadores, também podem ser de dispositivos de rede com o serviço
SNMP habilitado, como roteadores, impressoras, CPEs (modem ou roteador
de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes), entre outros.

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o servico SNMP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no
   equipamento, caso não esteja em uso.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SNMP habilitado, por favor repasse essa
mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* snmp: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e pacotes/bytes
   indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em pacotes/bytes.

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_2b88d034ae]     | 2716   | OPEN   | 2023-05-04T18:05:47Z | snmp: open/1/106
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]
            ```

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]

Incident: 
        You are a security expert.
        Categorize the following incident description into a Category and an Explanation.

        Description:
            ``` [target]: [[DATE_TIME_c2c0b98951] 15:59 CERT.br: 
Data de envio: May 4, 2023 3:57 PM
Para: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servico SNMP habilitado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua
responsabilidade com o servico SNMP (161/udp) habilitado. Este serviço
pode ser abusado para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação
de serviço, consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados, além de servidores e
computadores, também podem ser de dispositivos de rede com o serviço
SNMP habilitado, como roteadores, impressoras, CPEs (modem ou roteador
de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes), entre outros.

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o servico SNMP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no
   equipamento, caso não esteja em uso.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SNMP habilitado, por favor repasse essa
mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* snmp: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e pacotes/bytes
   indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em pacotes/bytes.

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_2b88d034ae]     | 2716   | OPEN   | 2023-05-04T18:05:47Z | snmp: open/1/106
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_2b88d034ae]     | 2716   | OPEN   | 2023-05-04T18:05:47Z | snmp: open/1/106

Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]

Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servico SNMP habilitado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua
responsabilidade com o servico SNMP (161/udp) habilitado. Este serviço
pode ser abusado para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação
de serviço, consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados, além de servidores e
computadores, também podem ser de dispositivos de rede com o serviço
SNMP habilitado, como roteadores, impressoras, CPEs (modem ou roteador
de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes), entre outros.

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o servico SNMP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SNMP habilitado, por favor repasse essa
mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* snmp: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e pacotes/bytes
   indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em pacotes/bytes.

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_2b88d034ae]     | 2716   | OPEN   | 2023-05-04T18:05:47Z | snmp: open/1/106
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]
            ```

We are given an incident description from CERT.br about SNMP being enabled on devices that are potentially vulnerable to DDoS attacks. The key points are:
- The notification is about devices (IPs) having SNMP (port 161/udp) enabled and exposed to the internet.
- This service can be abused for DDoS attacks (amplification attacks).
- The incident is a notification that the service is exposed and possibly being abused.

We are to categorize this incident into one of the NIST categories (CAT1 to CAT12).

Let me recall the NIST categories (as per the context of the problem):

- CAT1: Account Compromise
- CAT2: Malware
- CAT3: Denial of Service Attack
- CAT4: Data Leak
- CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation
- CAT6: Unauthorized Access
- CAT7: Network Infiltration
- CAT8: Identity Theft
- CAT9: Physical Security Breach
- CAT10: Regulatory Violation
- CAT11: Business Continuity Disruption
- CAT12: Intrusion Attempt (unconfirmed attacks)

The incident description is the notification from CERT.br to the organization that they have devices with SNMP enabled that are exposed and could be abused for DDoS attacks.

Important note: The email says "possivelmente estão sendo abusados" (possibly being abused). So it's a potential risk, not confirmed exploitation.

However, in the context of incident classification, we have to see which category fits best.

Analysis:

- **CAT3: Denial of Service Attack**: This category is for active DoS/DDoS attacks. The incident here is a notification of a vulnerability that could be exploited to cause DDoS, not an active attack. The email does not state that an attack has occurred. So CAT3 is not applicable.

- **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation**: This category is defined as "using technical flaws for attacks". The technical flaw here is the exposed SNMP service (which is a configuration vulnerability). The email states that this service "can be abused" (i.e., it is a vulnerability that could be exploited for DDoS attacks). Moreover, the email says the devices "possivelmente estão sendo abusados" (possibly being abused), which implies that the vulnerability is being used (or is under active threat of use). Therefore, this incident is a case of a vulnerability that is being exploited (or potentially being exploited) for attacks. This seems to fit.

- **CAT12: Intrusion Attempt (unconfirmed attacks)**: This category includes unconfirmed attacks such as network scans, brute force, blocked exploits. The incident here is not an active intrusion attempt (like a scan) but rather a notification about a vulnerability that the organization might have. The email is a security alert about a vulnerability, not an intrusion attempt by an attacker. Therefore, CAT12 is not the best fit.

Why CAT5?
The NIST category CAT5 is specifically for when a vulnerability is being exploited. In this case, the vulnerability (exposed SNMP) is a technical flaw that, when exploited, can be used for DDoS attacks. The email from CERT.br is a notification that the organization has such a vulnerability and it is being targeted (possibly already in use). So it is a vulnerability exploitation event.

Moreover, the description says: "Este serviço pode ser abusado" (this service can be abused) and "possivelmente estão sendo abusados" (possibly being abused). This indicates that the service is under attack or at risk of being exploited.

Therefore, the incident should be categorized as **CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation**.

Let me double-check with the provided examples in the problem (though not explicitly given, but based on common knowledge):

- CAT5: Example: A vulnerability (like a misconfigured service) that is being exploited by an attacker to gain unauthorized access or cause a DoS.

In this case, the vulnerability (exposed SNMP) is being exploited (or potentially) for DDoS attacks. So it fits.

Conclusion: Category = CAT5

The key phrase "possivelmente estão sendo abusados" (possibly being abused) indicates that the vulnerability is under active threat of exploitation or already being used by attackers, aligning with the NIST definition of **Vulnerability Exploitation (CAT5)**—where technical flaws are leveraged for attacks. This is distinct from CAT3 (active DoS attacks) because the incident describes a *potential risk* and *targeted vulnerability*, not confirmed attack activity. CAT12 (Intrusion Attempt) is also not applicable, as the notification originates from CERT.br (not an unconfirmed attacker action) and focuses on vulnerability exposure rather than scanning/brute-force attempts. Thus, CAT5 best captures the exploitation of the technical flaw (SNMP exposure) for DDoS purposes.

prompt:
Incident: 
        You are a security expert.
        Categorize the following incident description into a Category and an Explanation.

        Description:
            ``` [target]: [[DATE_TIME_c2c0b98951] 15:59 CERT.br: 
Data de envio: May 4, 2023 3:57 PM
Para: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servico SNMP habilitado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são de servidores sob sua
responsabilidade com o servico SNMP (161/udp) habilitado. Este serviço
pode ser abusado para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação
de serviço, consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados, além de servidores e
computadores, também podem ser de dispositivos de rede com o serviço
SNMP habilitado, como roteadores, impressoras, CPEs (modem ou roteador
de uso doméstico instalado nos clientes), entre outros.

Gostaríamos de solicitar que:

* o servico SNMP seja configurado corretamente ou desabilitado no
   equipamento, caso não esteja em uso.

Uma descrição do problema e possíveis soluções podem ser encontradas
no final deste documento.

Se você não for a pessoa correta para corrigir o problema destes
equipamentos com o serviço SNMP habilitado, por favor repasse essa
mensagem para alguém de sua organização que possa fazê-lo.

O indicador no campo 'Resultados do Teste' indica o tipo de problema
testado e significa:

* snmp: status/pacotes/bytes, onde status é "open", e pacotes/bytes
   indicam o tamanho da resposta recebida, em pacotes/bytes.

====================================================================================
Endereco IP      | ASN    | Status | Data do Teste        | Resultados do Teste
[IP_ADDRESS_2b88d034ae]     | 2716   | OPEN   | 2023-05-04T18:05:47Z | snmp: open/1/106
====================================================================================
Mais detalhes sobre o porque do envio desta mensagem, quem é o
CERT.br e como resolver este problema estão listados abaixo.

Cordialmente,
-- 
CERT.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]
            ```

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos

  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad]
